facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 145-A of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 145- A of 1954. Appeal under Article 132

facts.text: Appeal under Article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated July 23,

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated July 23, 1954 of Madras High Court in Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 922 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated July 23, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 922 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from Madras High Court that case involved substantial question of law as to interpretation of Constitution under Art. 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant obtained a certificate from the Madras High Court to the effect that the case involved a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution under Art. 132 1 ,

facts.text: Respondent filed petition in High Court under s.491 CrPC for habeas corpus directions for production and release from imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: in companysequence of which the present appeal is before us. The respondent had filed a petition in the High Court under s. 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure praying that directions in the nature of habeas companypus may be issued for his production before That Court to be dealt with according to law and for his release from imprisonment.

facts.text: Respondent arrested on June 1, 1954 pursuant to warrant issued on March 10, 1954 by Collector of Malabar under s.48 of Madras Revenue Recovery Act (Act 11 of 1864).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been arrested on June 1, 1954 in pursuance of a warrant issued on March 10, 1954 by the Collector of Malabar under s. 48 of the Madras Revenue Recovery Act  Madras Act 11 of 1864   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Respondent assessed to income-tax for various years, total outstanding tax Rs.70,000 approximately.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances, as stated in the affidavits filed by the Collector and the Income Tax Officer of Kozikhode in the High Court, which led to the respondents arrest, were, that he had been assessed to income-tax for various assessment years and the total amount of tax remaining outstanding against him, in round figures, was Rs. 70,000.

facts.text: Some amount recovered by Collector pursuant to certificate under s.46(2) Income Tax Act and by ITO under s.46(5A).

anchor.surface_text: Some amount was recovered by the Collector in pursuance of a certificate issued by the Income Tax Officer under s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act and bY the Income Tax Officer himself under s. 46 5 A of the said Act.

facts.text: After deductions, arrears of income-tax Rs.61,668 for assessment years 1943-44, 1945-46 to 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: After deducting the amount so realised the arrears of income-tax were about Rs. 61,668 and odd for the assessment Years 1943-44, 1945 -46 to 1948-49.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer discovered respondent sold properties between November 18, 1947 and March 25, 1948 for about Rs.23,100.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile the Income Tax Officer had made enquiries into the affairs of the respondent and had discovered that he had sold certain properties of his between November 18, 1947 and March 25, 1948 to the tune of about Rs. 23,100.

facts.text: Demand notice served on respondent on November 6, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Demand numberice had been served upon him on November 6, 1947 and the series of transactions of sale started on November 18, 1947.

facts.text: Out of Rs.23,100 from sales, respondent paid Rs.10,500 arrears of tax.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the said sum of Rs. 23,100, the respondent paid arrears of tax to the extent of Rs. 10,500 only.

facts.text: Respondent closed business at Cannanore in August 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Enquiries also revealed that although the respondent had closed his business at Cannanore in August, 1947, he had set up a firm in 1948 at Tellichery carrying on an identical business in the name of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros.

facts.text: Respondent set up firm V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros in 1948 at Tellichery with one major and four minor sons.

anchor.surface_text: he had set up a firm in 1948 at Tellichery carrying on an identical business in the name of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros. companysisting of his one major and four minor sons.

facts.text: Respondent alleged capital of firm supplied from sale of wife's jewels.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had alleged that the capital of this firm was mainly supplied from the sale of jewels belonging to his wife, that is, Abdul Azeezs mother.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer found source of jewels not proved and held business of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros belonged to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: He denied that the above-mentioned firm belonged to him. In the assessment proceedings before the Income Tax Officer companycerning the firm V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros., the source of these jewels was gone into, but it was found that the same had number been proved and it was held that the business of V.P. Abdul Azeez Bros. belonged to the respondent.

facts.text: Facts communicated to Collector by ITO; Collector made independent enquiries.

anchor.surface_text: All these facts were companymunicated to the Collector by the Income Tax Officer who made independent enquiries for himself

facts.text: Collector had reason to believe respondent wilfully withholding payment of arrears and guilty of fraudulent conduct evading tax.

anchor.surface_text: and had reason to believe that the respondent was wilfully withholding payment of arrears of tax and had been guilty of fraudulent companyduct in evading payment of tax.

facts.text: Certificate issued to Collector by ITO under s.46(2) Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: As a certificate had already been issued to him by the Income Tax Officer under s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act,

facts.text: Collector proceeded under s.48 Act, issued warrant, respondent arrested and lodged in Central Jail, Cannanore.

anchor.surface_text: the Collector proceeded under s. 48 of the Act to issue a warrant of arrest against the respondent in companysequence of which he was arrested and lodged in Central Jail, Cannanore.

facts.text: High Court petition under s.491 CrPC heard by Mack and Krishnaswami Nayudu JJ, allowed, ordered respondent set at liberty as arrest illegal.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, the petition under s. 491, Criminal Procedure Code, was heard by Mack and Krishna. swamy Nayudu JJ. which was allowed and they ordered that the respondent be set at liberty as his arrest was illegal.

facts.text: Mack J held s.48 Act ultra vires Art.22, and s.46(2) Income Tax Act ultra vires Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: Mack J. thought that s. 48 of the Act was ultra vires the Constitution as it offended Art. 22. He did number deal at length with the argument that s. 48 offended Art. 21 as he was of the opinion that if that section was ultra vires,

facts.text: Krishnaswami Nayudu J held s.46(2) Income Tax Act read with s.48 Act offends Art.14 and s.48 offends Art.21 and Art.22(2).

anchor.surface_text: Krishnaswami Nayudu J. was of the opinion that s.46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act read with s. 48 of the Act offended Art. 14 of the Constitution. He was of the opinion that s. 48 of the Act offended Art. 21 of the Constitution to the extent that it afforded numberopportunity to the arrested person to appear before the Collector by himself or through a legal practitioner of his choice and to urge before him any defence open to him and that it did number provide for the production of the arrested person within 24 hours before a magistrate as required by Art. 22 2 .

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on April 11, 1957 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta and R. H. Dhebar, for the appellants. Pocker and B. K. B. Naidu, for the respondent. 1957. April 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held neither s.48 Act nor s.46(2) Income Tax Act violates Arts.14,19,21,22 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the previous decisions of this Court referred to above, neither s. 48 of the Act number s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act violates Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

facts.text: Affidavits filed in High Court by Collector and Income Tax Officer of Kozhikode detailing circumstances leading to arrest.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances, as stated in the affidavits filed by the Collector and the Income Tax Officer of Kozikhode in the High Court, which led to the respondents arrest, were,

facts.text: Collector justified in arresting respondent based on material in affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavits filed in the High Court by the Collector and the Income Tax Officer it is quite clear that there was material upon which the Collector companyld base his belief that the respondent was wilfully withholding payment of the arrears of -tax and had been guilty of fraudulent companyduct in order to evade payment.

facts.text: Respondent about 70 years old at time of arrest, suffering from serious ill health including paralysis.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the respondent was a man of about 70 years at the time of his arrest and a Person suffering from serious ill health. Indeed, it is said, he is suffering from paralysis

anchor.surface_text: The authority given to the Collector by this section is to recover the arrears of tax as if it were an arrear of land revenue... Section 48 provides... arrest of the defaulter is one of the modes...

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavits filed in the High Court by the Collector and the Income Tax Officer it is quite clear that there was material upon which the Collector companyld base his belief that the respondent was wilfully withholding payment of the arrears of -tax and had been guilty of fraudulent companyduct in order to evade payment.

arguments.claim: release possible on payment via proviso s.46(2) IT Act and s.58 CPC

holdings.text: neither s. 48 of the Act nor s. 46(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act violates Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, having regard to the previous decisions of this Court referred to above, neither s. 48 of the Act nor s. 46 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act violates Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows prior Supreme Court decisions in Gopalan, Ajaib Singh, and Purshottam Govindji Halai cases upholding validity of similar recovery provisions against constitutional challenges

holdings.text: the respondent was deprived of his personal liberty in accordance with a procedure established by valid law under Art. 21

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal before us, the principal question, therefore, is whether the respondent was deprived of his personal liberty in accordance with a procedure established by law, i.e., a valid law. If the law is valid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 21 requires procedure by valid law; s.46(2) IT Act and s.48 MRRA held valid, constituting such procedure; controls Art.19 rights per Gopalan

holdings.text: s. 46(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act authorizes arrest of the defaulter as a mode of recovery of arrears of tax as land revenue

anchor.surface_text: The authority given to the Collector by this section is to recover the arrears of tax as if it were an arrear of land revenue. The preamble of the Act clearly states that the laws relating to the collection of the public revenue should be consolidated and simplified and s. 5 provides for the manner in which the arrears of revenue may be recovered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: s.46(2) deems tax arrears as land revenue recoverable per MRRA s.5 (property sale or execution against person) and s.48 (arrest when property insufficient and wilful/fraudulent default)

holdings.text: s. 48 of the Act does not require the Collector to give the defaulter an opportunity to be heard before issuing warrant of arrest

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in s. 48 of the Act which requires the Collector to give the defaulter an opportunity to be heard before arresting him. It is true that the Collector must have reason to believe that the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain text of s.48 imposes no prior hearing requirement; reason to believe forms from material, reviewable by court if rational

holdings.text: the Collector had reason to believe that the respondent was wilfully withholding payment of arrears or guilty of fraudulent conduct, justifying the arrest

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavits filed in the High Court by the Collector and the Income Tax Officer it is quite clear that there was material upon which the Collector could base his belief that the respondent was wilfully withholding payment of the arrears of -tax and had been guilty of fraudulent conduct in order to evade payment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit material (property sales post-demand, benami firm, unproven jewel source) provides rational basis for belief; court reviews sufficiency

holdings.text: there is provision for release of the defaulter on payment of arrears under s. 48 read with s. 46(2)

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 58 of the Civil Procedure Code a Civil Court must release the judgment debtor if the amount due is paid. Accordingly, the Collector has the power to release the defaulter if the amount due is

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.46(2) IT Act confers civil court powers (s.58 CPC release on payment); payment removes s.48 precondition of arrears

holdings.text: arrest under s.48 is for civil debt recovery, not criminal detention attracting Art.22

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the arrest was not in connection with any allegation... It was really an arrest for a civil debt in the process or the mode prescribed by law for recovery of arrears of land revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes from criminal/quasi-criminal arrest per Ajaib Singh; recovery coercion, not punishment for offence

holdings.text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the judgment of the High Court is set aside

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding sections unconstitutional and arrest illegal; reversed on above grounds

precedents.citation: A. K. Gopalan v. The State Of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: A. K. Gopalan v. The State Of Madras 1

precedents.case_name: A. K. Gopalan v. The State Of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: procedure established by law means procedure enacted by a law made by the State; Art. 19(1)(d) controlled by Art. 21; personal liberty rights under Art. 19 subordinate to Art. 21
precedents.cited_holding: the right to move freely throughout the territory of India referred to in Art. 19(1)(d) ... was but one of the many attributes included in the concept of the right to personal liberty and when a person is lawfully deprived of his personal liberty without offending Art. 21, he cannot claim to exercise any of the rights guaranteed by sub-cls. (a) to (e) and (g) of Art. 19(1)

anchor.surface_text: The State of Punjab v.Ajaib Singh 1

precedents.case_name: The State of Punjab v. Ajaib Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: taking into custody under recovery act not arrest or detention within meaning of Art. 22 if not connected to criminal offence
precedents.cited_holding: the taking into custody was not arrest and detention within the meaning of Art. 22; physical restraint put upon an abducted person in the process of recovering ... cannot be regarded as an arrest or detention within the meaning of Art. 22

precedents.case_name: Purshottam Govindji Halai v. Shree B. B. Desai, Additional Collector of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: arrest for recovery of income tax arrears certified under s.46(2) as land revenue under revenue recovery act constitutes procedure established by law, not violating Arts. 14 or 21; s.46(2) not ultra vires Art. 14
precedents.cited_holding: there was no violation of Art. 21 ... where a person had been arrested under s. 13 of the Bombay Land Revenue Act 1876 in pursuance of a warrant of arrest issued for recovery of the demand certified under s. 46(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act, which did not offend Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: The authority given to the Collector by this section is to recover the arrears of tax as if it were an arrear of land revenue. The preamble of the Act clearly states that the laws relating to the collection of the public revenue should be consolidated and simplified and s. 5 provides for the manner in which the arrears of revenue may be recovered.
The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.
